result.execSummary:
Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Defendant Garrit J Schlenz in court with attorney Patrick Kiernan Cafferty.  Dirk C Jensen appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court Reporter: Darlene Shue.  15CM1505  plea to counts 1 and 2 - CM theft and 1 battery count.  DRI 15CF857.  PLQ is filed.   Judge conducts plea colloquey.  Defendant pleas G and is found G by the court.  State presents it's sentencing argument.  Defense presents it's sentencing argument.  Spent time in the Detention Center.  Defense requests expungment.  State objects to expungment.  Mother JS speaks to the Court regarding a treatment

w/h 2 yrs probation
Conditions:  
Engage in treatment meet with psychiatrist as scheduled
no alco or drugs not prescribed to you by a dr.  AODA assessment and ft with recommendation
HS diploma
employment
no restitution request
No contact with Pick N Save on Green Bay Rd.
60 days RCJ, stayed to be used for enforcement purposes  CFTS from Detention
20 hrs. CSW
Counseling as deemed appropriate 
DNA sample and surcharge
CC are waived
Upon successful completion of  probation defendant may request expungment of15CM1505.   15CF857 and 15CF1499 are dismissed or DRI cases.  Research will have to be done regarding those cases.
